title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one benefit to human health that can result from pesticide use, such as any of the following:

· Control disease vectors, such as mosquitos, ticks, rats, mice, that can spread diseases to humans/between humans.

· Reduce exposure to stinging insects that carry disease.

· Increased food production leads to decreased famine/increased availability of food, improving human health.

The response describes one benefit to human health that can result from pesticide use, such as one of the following:

· Control disease vectors, such as mosquitos, ticks, rats, mice, that can spread diseases to humans/between humans.

· Reduce exposure to stinging insects that carry disease.

· Increased food production leads to decreased famine/increased availability of food, improving human health.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify one way chemical pesticides can enter the human body, such as any of the following:

· Inhalation/Breathing (in aerosols and powders)

· Drinking water contaminated by runoff (from farms, yards, golf courses, etc.)

· Consumption of food (Pesticide residue on or in food eaten by consumers)

· Dermal absorption/through skin during application of pesticide

The response identifies one way chemical pesticides can enter the human body, such as one of the following:

· Inhalation/Breathing (in aerosols and powders)

· Drinking water contaminated by runoff (from farms, yards, golf courses, etc.)

· Consumption of food (Pesticide residue on or in food eaten by consumers)

· Dermal absorption/through skin during application of pesticide

title: Part C(i)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the year when the pesticide was most effective at reducing the size of the pest population as 1975.
The response identifies the year when the pesticide was most effective at reducing the size of the pest population as 1975.

title: Part C(ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the change in the number of crop insect pests in the cotton fields over time, such as any of the following:

· From 1960 to 2015 the number of pests captures increased from 700 to 1100.

· The number of pests was high before the pesticide was used, then it dropped dramatically after the first application, and then increased again over time.

· The number of pests went from 2 captured in 1975 to 1100 captures in 2015.

The response describes the change in the number of crop insect pests in the cotton fields over time, such as one of the following:

· From 1960 to 2015 the number of pests captures increased from 700 to 1100.

· The number of pests was high before the pesticide was used, then it dropped dramatically after the first application, and then increased again over time.

· The number of pests went from 2 captured in 1975 to 1100 captures in 2015.

title: Part C(iii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how the cotton-crop pesticide effectiveness between the initial application in 1975 and the latest application in 2015 illustrates genetic resistance in pests, based on the data, such as any of the following:

· Over time the number of pests that are killed decreases (more pests are found in traps) and more pesticide has to be applied (increased grams per hectare) because the pests that are resistant to the pesticide survive and reproduce, passing along resistance to the pesticide.

· The data in the table illustrates the pesticide treadmill, where each year more pesticide has to be applied and fewer pests die because following application only pests with resistance to the pesticide survive and reproduce.

· Pesticide effectiveness following the initial application in 1975 decreased over time. Regardless of whether application quantities was constant (1975-1985) or increased (1990-2015) the number of pests captured steadily increased because an increasing number of surviving pests had genetic resistance to the pesticide.

The response explains how the cotton-crop pesticide effectiveness between the initial application in 1975 and the latest application in 2015 illustrates genetic resistance in pests, based on the data, such as one of the following:

· Over time the number of pests that are killed decreases (more pests are found in traps) and more pesticide has to be applied (increased grams per hectare) because the pests that are resistant to the pesticide survive and reproduce, passing along resistance to the pesticide.

· The data in the table illustrates the pesticide treadmill, where each year more pesticide has to be applied and fewer pests die because following application only pests with resistance to the pesticide survive and reproduce.

· Pesticide effectiveness following the initial application in 1975 decreased over time. Regardless of whether application quantities was constant (1975-1985) or increased (1990-2015) the number of pests captured steadily increased because an increasing number of surviving pests had genetic resistance to the pesticide.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe TWO effects of pesticide use, other than death, on non-target wildlife, such as any of the following:

· The pesticide may contaminate soil/water having a negative impact on organisms.

· The pesticide may bioaccumulate in the body of the organisms.

· The pesticide may biomagnify in the food web/chain of the organisms.

· There may be an increase in the population of non-target organisms unaffected by the pesticide that will have new areas of habitat available to them.

· There could be a decrease in predator species so prey species will grow rapidly.

· Endocrine disruption leading to reproductive/development abnormalities.

· Chemicals disrupt signaling/communication in bees.

· Lead to thinning of egg shells/developmental abnormalities in organisms.

· Eliminates food supply; disrupts food chain for other species.

The response only describes ONE effect of pesticide use, other than death, on non-target wildlife, such as one of the following:

· The pesticide may contaminate soil/water having a negative impact on organisms.

· The pesticide may bioaccumulate in the body of the organisms.

· The pesticide may biomagnify in the food web/chain of the organisms.

· There may be an increase in the population of non-target organisms unaffected by the pesticide that will have new areas of habitat available to them.

· There could be a decrease in predator species so prey species will grow rapidly.

· Endocrine disruption leading to reproductive/development abnormalities.

· Chemicals disrupt signaling/communication in bees.

· Lead to thinning of egg shells/developmental abnormalities in organisms.

· Eliminates food supply; disrupts food chain for other species.

The response describes TWO effects of pesticide use, other than death, on non-target wildlife, such as two of the following:

· The pesticide may contaminate soil/water having a negative impact on organisms.

· The pesticide may bioaccumulate in the body of the organisms.

· The pesticide may biomagnify in the food web/chain of the organisms.

· There may be an increase in the population of non-target organisms unaffected by the pesticide that will have new areas of habitat available to them.

· There could be a decrease in predator species so prey species will grow rapidly.

· Endocrine disruption leading to reproductive/development abnormalities.

· Chemicals disrupt signaling/communication in bees.

· Lead to thinning of egg shells/developmental abnormalities in organisms.

· Eliminates food supply; disrupts food chain for other species.

title: Part E(i)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the process of crop rotation, such as any of the following:

· The process of growing different crops in succession on the same piece of land.

· The process of growing different crops in the same area during different seasons.

· The process of harvesting one crop followed by the planting of a different crop in the same area.

The response describes the process of crop rotation, such as one of the following:

· The process of growing different crops in succession on the same piece of land.

· The process of growing different crops in the same area during different seasons.

· The process of harvesting one crop followed by the planting of a different crop in the same area.

title: Part E(ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not propose one reasonable method, other than crop rotation, to reduce the use of pesticides in agricultural practices while still maintaining a high crop yield, such as any of the following:

· Use integrated pest management to control the insect crop pest.

· Use a method of pest control that employs a variety of biological, physical and chemical methods to control the insect crop pest.

· Reduce stubble/crop residues in fallow fields that can harbor the insect crop pest.

· Apply the pesticide when the insect crop pest is most susceptible.

· Use intercropping rather than a monoculture to reduce the amount of habitat for the pests.

· Use pest-resistant genetically modified organisms.

The response proposes one reasonable method, other than crop rotation, to reduce the use of pesticides in agricultural practices while still maintaining a high crop yield, such as one of the following:

· Use integrated pest management to control the insect crop pest.

· Use a method of pest control that employs a variety of biological, physical and chemical methods to control the insect crop pest.

· Reduce stubble/crop residues in fallow fields that can harbor the insect crop pest.

· Apply the pesticide when the insect crop pest is most susceptible.

· Use intercropping rather than a monoculture to reduce the amount of habitat for the pests.

· Use pest-resistant genetically modified organisms.

title: Part E(iii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not justify how the method proposed in (e)(ii) would provide a benefit to humans, such as any of the following:

· Reduction in pesticide residue in food/reduction of pesticide ingested by humans.

· Economic benefits to humans including:

o Less money spent on pesticides

o Increased profit for farmers from crops

o Less equipment required/less labor required to spray fields with pesticides

· Reduction in number of workers exposed to pesticides/Improved health in agricultural workers from reduced pesticide exposure.

The response justifies how the method proposed in (e)(ii) would provide a benefit to humans, such as one of the following:

· Reduction in pesticide residue in food/reduction of pesticide ingested by humans.

· Economic benefits to humans including:

o Less money spent on pesticides

o Increased profit for farmers from crops

o Less equipment required/less labor required to spray fields with pesticides

· Reduction in number of workers exposed to pesticides/Improved health in agricultural workers from reduced pesticide exposure.
